title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — In a defensive battle that scraped the paint and bent rims, the Indiana Pacers gritted out an 82-78 victory over the Miami Heat in a classic 1998 Eastern Conference showdown. But this was not merely a win; it was a coronation for a warrior, a historic performance etched into the annals of the game by Pacers center Rik Smits.

On a night where points were a premium, Smits was an unstoppable force, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 44 points. The “Dunkin’ Dutchman” was a study in efficiency and dominance, converting 18 of his 26 attempts from the field and imposing his will in the post against a helpless Miami defense. Every possession was a potential masterpiece, with Smits scoring from the block, facing up, and hitting his trademark soft-touch jumpers.

While Smits orchestrated the offense, the game hung in the balance until the final moments. The Heat, led by Tim Hardaway’s 19 points and Alonzo Mourning’s 13 points and 13 rebounds, clawed back from a double-digit deficit, turning the contest into a typical, physical 90s slugfest. But for every Miami run, there was an answer from Smits, a calming presence in the storm.

The Pacers’ other stalwarts played their roles to perfection. Reggie Miller, despite an off-shooting night, contributed 11 points and 6 assists, while Chris Mullin added 10 points. Their efforts, combined with Smits’ transcendent outing, were just enough to hold off the Heat’s furious charge.

When the final horn sounded, the scoreboard told the story of a narrow Pacers win. But the stat sheet, and the memory of those in attendance, told a far grander tale: the night Rik Smits scored 44, carrying his team on his broad shoulders and securing his place in Indiana basketball lore.
